title: Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang joins elite Arsenal group after winning award
text:
Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang has been confirmed as the Premier League Player of the Month for September (Picture: Getty)

Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang has been confirmed as the Premier League Player of the Month for September.

The Arsenal striker beat the likes of Liverpool full-back Trent Alexander-Arnold, Manchester City’s assist machine Kevin De Bruyne, a rejuvenated Riyad Mahrez and Tottenham forward Son Heung-min.

Aubameyang began the month by scoring the equaliser in the north London derby and struck twice in a 2-2 draw against Watford. The Gabon international notched a dramatic late winning goal with a sumptuous free kick against Aston Villa and ended September with a smartly taken goal in a 1-1 draw against Manchester United at Old Trafford.

5 – @Aubameyang7 is the fifth Arsenal player to have won multiple Premier League player of the month awards, after Dennis Bergkamp (4), Thierry Henry (4), Robin van Persie (3) and Cesc Fabregas (2). Panther. pic.twitter.com/zWfosF2tFh — OptaJoe (@OptaJoe) October 11, 2019

It is the second time the 30-year-old has scooped the prestigious award and in the process becomes only the fifth Arsenal player to have won it on multiple occasions with Dennis Bergkamp (four), Thierry Henry (four), Robin van Persie (three) and Cesc Fabregas (two) the other members of an elite group.

Aubameyang’s importance to the Arsenal cause was also highlighted by Unai Emery’s decision to appoint the former Borussia Dortmund striker as the club’s vice-captain.

‘He is an experienced player now,’ Emery said last week. ‘He played in France, Germany and now in England at a high level and with a high performance. His experience is good, his team-mates decided with the vote that they wanted him as vice-captain.

‘I am usually speaking with him and now he is more confident and more mature in the Premier League compared to when I arrived last year, he came only six months before me.

‘He scored a lot of goals last year but has now also taken a big responsibility within the team and he is one of the captains who can manage in the dressing room.

‘I will speak with him in my office, the hotel or the dressing room. First, we built a human connection and then as a player and then I know I can ask him what I want and what the team needs – he always listens and will always give his best to provide that.

‘He will play all minutes, some minutes, all games if we ask that of him and he is always ready to play again – this is also showing his leadership qualities.’
